label: BB001_01
name: Problem formulation A1
description: Enter a description of the problem formulation, which is is aimed at defining the purpose and scope of a risk assessment and the depth of the analysis. Please include the relevant regulation(s) that must be considered if an assessment is required for regulatory purposes. Also include the envisaged exposure scenario(s), the substance definition, etc. Give an indication on the level/uncertainty limits of the desired information. If possible: specify the areas of toxicity (knowledge gap to be filled), the level of need for mechanistic understanding and potential exit points (sufficient information reached)
method_link:
- National Research Council. 2009. Science and Decisions: Advancing Risk Assessment. https://nap.nationalacademies.org/read/12209/chapter/1
- US EPA. 2014. Framework for human health risk assessment to inform decision making. https://www.epa.gov/sites/def

label: BB002_01
name: Relevant existing data for substance of interest?
description: Search for available physicochemical, toxicological, mechanistic and toxicokinetic data about this compound in existing data sources. Compile all available data on exposure levels. Provide a transparent information overview, based on these data.

label: DP01EF_01
name: Information sufficient?
description: Justify if existing data is sufficient for answering the question posed in the Problem Formulation. If information is considered sufficient (Yes), record the basis for this decision. If information is considered insufficient, specify the knowledge gaps or remaining uncertainties.

label: BB003_01
name: Derive Point-of-Departure POD
description: Compile all data from assays considered to be predictive of hazard. For each assay, determine concentration dependency of the effect, fit a function through the data points and determine the minimum concentration, at which hazard may be triggered (BMC or BMCL). Give a rationale why and how this BMC has been chosen. Compile all BMCs and determine which of them is considered most relevant. This one is termed PoD. Give a rationale for the choice and indicate the uncertainty of the decision. Decide (and justify) whether a single PoD is chosen or whether multiple PoD are chosen. In the latter case decide and justify whether the multiple PoD are collapsed to a single value (variance) is chosen, or whether work is continued with a distribution function of PoD.

label: DP02EF_01
name: Is read-across applicable?
description: Consider read-across as alternative approach for addressing the regulatory question(s) at hand. Justify in the application of read-accross can answer the question posed in the Problem Formulation.

label: WF01_01
name: Perform dedicated workflow for NAM-based read-across
description: Make use of existing data (in vivo, in vitro, etc.) to carry out read-across, using grouping or analogue approaches. Depending on the regulatory context the following guidelines could be useful (it).

label: DP03EF_01
name: Information sufficient?
description: Justify if existing data is sufficient for answering the question posed in the Problem Formulation. If information is considered sufficient (Yes), record the basis for this decision. If information is considered insufficient, specify the knowledge gaps or remaining uncertainties.

label: BB040_01
name: Identify data gap and testing strategy based on problem formulation
description: Consider whether the regulatory question(s) at hand can be addressed using NAMs. If so, outline necessary steps for hazard, ADME and exposure, where appropriate.

label: DP04EF_01
name: Is NAM -based testing feasible for the substance of interest
description: Evaluate if the substance of interest has physico-chemical properties, which would interfere with its testing in the proposed NAMs methods coming from BB040

label: BB008_01
name: Generate in silico predictions of hazard
description: Generate QSAR predictions for relevant bioactivity (e.g. AOP MIE or other KEs) and hazard (AOP AO). Use the query compound as input for a panel of QSAR models (e.g. collected at DTU). Ideally use various panels/tools.

label: BB009_01
name: Generate high-throughput in vitro data
description: Use an assembly of assays that broadly characterize bioactivity of the compound at question over a large concentration range. Example for such assays (RH3R version of ASPA) are stress reporter assays, luciferase signal transduction assays, cytotoxicity assays in 3 cell lines (proliferating HepG2, LUHMES, RPTEC), and a transcriptomic assay in HepG2 cells. [Possibly expand the battery by an assay for AChE activity, a MEA assay and a metabolic activation assay (PHH)]. Determine concentration ranges with no effect, potentially specific effects, and of general cytotoxicity. Use various routines to identify relevant modes of action (for toxicity), based on bioactivity data.

label: BB010_01
name: Integration of results
description: Analyze and integrate the results obtained in previous steps.

label: DP06EF_01
name: Alert for genotoxicity, eye irritation, skin irritation or sensitization?
description:
Did in silico or in vitro NAMs predict any alert for genotoxicity, eye irritation, skin irritation and/or skin sensitization? If so, dedicated approaches are needed to confirm and characterize these alerts.
Justify if existing data is sufficient for answering the question posed in the Problem Formulation.

label: BB011_01
name: Defined approaches and/or dedicated tests to confirm or characterize alert
description: Defined approaches and/or dedicated tests to confirm or characterize alert.

label: BB012_01
name: Integration of results
description: Analyze and integrate the results obtained in previous steps.

label: DP07EF_01
name: Information sufficient?
description: Justify if existing data is sufficient for answering the question posed in the Problem Formulation. If information is considered sufficient (Yes), record the basis for this decision. If information is considered insufficient, specify the knowledge gaps or remaining uncertainties.

label: BB013_01
name: Perform dedicated tests for data gap filling
description: Perform dedicated tests for data gap filling.

label: DP08EF_01
name: Toxicological alters identified? AOPs triggered?
description: Are any specific toxicological alerts identified? Are any alerts for perturbation of AOPs identified? If so, at what dose? Is this dose meaningful?

label: DP09EF_01
name: Information sufficient?
description: Justify if existing data is sufficient for answering the question posed in the Problem Formulation. If information is considered sufficient (Yes), record the basis for this decision. If information is considered insufficient (No), specify the knowledge gaps or remaining uncertainties.

label: BB015_01
name: Generate medium-throughput in vitro toxicity data e.g., for relevant qAOPs or Defined Approaches
description: This is a box that stands for a complex subroutine. The choice of NAM and the type of subroutine depends on the problem formulation and the data generated in more upstream parts. For some narrowly defined problem formulations, more defined subroutines can be constructed. For instance, if the problem formulation is about DNT, then this subroutine would include testing in teh DNT-IVB, as defined by teh OECD (GD377). If the problem formulation asks about clarification of potential renal toxicity, then models of respective cell types with overexpression of relevant transporters may be used, in combination with organoid approaches or organ-on-a-chip setups that connect e.g. kidney and liver tissues.

label: BB016_01
name: Integration of results
description: Analyze and integrate the results obtained in previous steps.

label: DP09EF_01
name: Information sufficient?
description: Justify if existing data is sufficient for answering the question posed in the Problem Formulation. If information is considered sufficient (Yes), record the basis for this decision. If information is considered insufficient, specify the knowledge gaps or remaining uncertainties.

label: BB017_01
name: Derive Point-of-Departure POD
description: Compile all data from assays considered to be predictive of hazard. For each assay, determine concentration dependency of the effect, fit a function through the data points and determine the minimum concentration, at which hazard may be triggered (BMC or BMCL). Give a rationale why and how this BMC has been chosen. Compile all BMCs and determine which of them is considered most relevant. This one is termed PoD. Give a rationale for the choice and indicate the uncertainty of the decision. Decide (and justify) whether a single PoD is chosen or whether multiple PoD are chosen. In the latter case decide and justify whether the multiple PoD are collapsed to a single value (variance) is chosen, or whether work is continued with a distribution function of PoD.

label: DP05EF_01
name: Compound mainly cleared by metabolism?
description: An assessment of the major clearance mechanism of the compound (metabolism vs renal vs biliary excretion unchanged. Document the (1) criteria that have been considered for the decision; (2) data that have been used; (3) effect thresholds considered relevant; (4) thresholds of certainty required for data used; (5) discussion points and possibly consistency checks that have been important for the decision. With evolution of NAMASTOX, increasing levels of guidance on above points will be incorporated in this decision point.

label: WF02_01
name: Perform dedicated workflow for metabolites
description: Assess relevance of metabolite formation using the dedicated workflow

label: DP03EF_01
name: Are ADME properties known?
description: Search for existing ADME data and properties (in vitro to in vivo). Which PBK model is appropriate? Is anything alerting for properties not covered by the httk model, then continue to Include information about the uptake (route specific)/fraction unbound in plasma, metabolism (like clearance in liver), blood to plasma ratio. Search of existing information.

label: BB003_01
name: Generate basic set of in silico and in vitro ADME data
description:
The type of data is dependent on the route of administration. A tiered approach is followed using in silico predictions and complementing them with in vitro data as far as needed. For oral route this as follows. 
Tier 0 - in silico based. This include information on the absorption in the gut (no metabolism); blood and plasma binding; and renal clearance. Very conservative approach overestimation of biovailable concentration because underestimating liver clearance.
Tier 1- complement with in vitro data
Predict if metabolism in liver is significant using suitable models such as the ECCS classification. If relevant, measure clearance in relevant in vitro system (like HLM, PHHs); measure permeability in vitro (gut: PAMPA assay, CACo-2 assays etc.).

label: BB004_01
name: Run PBPK model
description: Run PBPK model

label: DP04EF_01
name: Prediction of PBPK model acceptable?
description: Prediction of PBPK model acceptable?

label: BB005_01
name: Generated data for additional ADME parameters
description: Improve PBK model using more accurate in vitro ADME data e.g. to cover active transport/enzyme induction/inhibition/low clearance compounds. Alternatively improve PBK model by integrating other relevant ADME processes into the model structure like enterohepatic circulation, saturable metabolism etc.

label: BB006_01
name: Run PBK model
description: Run PBK model

label: DP05EF_01
name: Prediction of PBPK model acceptable?
description: Prediction of PBPK model acceptable?

label: BB007_01
name: Consider other types of relevant testing
description: Consider other types of relevant testing

label: BB014_01
name: Derive estimates of relevant test concentrations
description: Derive estimates of relevant test concentrations using available information on ADME properties. Use the result for hazard testing. This would be done on tier 0 data? and would be earlier in reality. You need a quick estimate for the hazard testing even if conservative? Also consider using highest concentration from human exposure as upper limit.

label: BB022_01
name: Screen possible exposure scenarios
description: Screening possible exposure scenarios involves systematically identifying and evaluating situations where individuals or the environment might come into contact with a substance on factors sources/pathways, volume distribution, target population (workers, consumers, general population), data/quantification. Collecting data of most suitable exposure modelling scenarios/available measurement data. Example questions to be answered: Description of possible sources and routes, resulting in a description of multiple scenarios. What is the target population (workers, consumers, general population)? Data availability search.

label: DP10EF_01
name: Is TTC applicable?
description: Is TTC applicable?

label: BB023_01
name: Estimate external exposure
description: Estimate external exposure

label: BB024_01
name: Determine maximum exposure Emax
description:
Calculate for each population the highest exposure (worst-case) for relevant source(s) and route(s) using the collected data and absorption efficiency. Considering factors such as frequency and duration. Outcome is the input for high-content in vitro data and HT PBK model
Input assumptions: problem formulation includes a defined exposure scenario. Output data: data, e.g, in mg/m3, mg/cm2 (+ exposed area), mg/day or mg/kg b.w./day of maximum exposure (concentration and dose?, dose for ranking below)

label: BB028_01
name: Calculate internal exposure using Emax
description: Calculate internal exposure using Emax

label: BB029_01
name: Refine exposure estimate, for example dominant pathway
description: Refine exposure estimate, for example dominant pathway

label: BB030_01
name: Calculate internal exposure, refined
description: Calculate internal exposure, refined

label: BB023_01
name: Estimate external exposure
description: Estimate external exposure

label: BB024_01
name: Determine maximum exposure Emax
description:
Calculate for each population the highest exposure (worst-case) for relevant source(s) and route(s) using the collected data and absorption efficiency. Considering factors such as frequency and duration. Outcome is the input for high-content in vitro data and HT PBK model
Input assumptions: problem formulation includes a defined exposure scenario. Output data: data, e.g, in mg/m3, mg/cm2 (+ exposed area), mg/day or mg/kg b.w./day of maximum exposure (concentration and dose?, dose for ranking below)

label: BB025_01
name: Perform TTC approach
description: Perform TTC approach

label: DP11EF_01
name: Is Emax lower than TTC?
description: Is Emax lower than TTC?

label: BB026_01
name: Refine estimation of Emax with further data
description: Refine estimation of Emax with further data

label: BB025_01
name: Perform TTC approach
description: Perform TTC approach

name: Is Emax lower than TTC?
description: Is Emax lower than TTC?

name: Compare POD with exposure
description: Compare POD with exposure.

label: DP14EF_01
name: Is the outcome acceptable?
description: Is the outcome acceptable?

label: DP12EF_01
name: Is deterministic refinement possible?
description: Refinement of the exposure estimate depending on the problem formulation. Iterative process which involves incorporation of new data, improving models and reducing uncertainties. This may involve additional data collection to improve the understanding of a specific exposure scenario.

label: DP13EF_01
name: Is probabilistic refinement possible?
description: Refinement of the estimate depending on the problem formulation, such as realistic scenarios for the population of interest and refined timing of exposure. Refine the exposure assessment using NAM data on additional ADME parameters such as bioaccumulation and excretion rates. This iterative process enhances the accuracy and reliability of the exposure estimates over time. Refine the aggregate exposure estimate by taking into account timing and duration of each exposure event.

label: BB032_01
name: Generate or collect data needed for probabilistic approaches
description: Generate or collect data needed for probabilistic approaches.

label: BB031_01
name: Calculate internal exposure, further refined
description: Calculate internal exposure, further refined.
